awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH-PGR: Variants and Recombinants without Meiosis
awd_abstract_narration:
During tissue culture, plant genomes undergo frequent unexpected changes resulting in plants with different characteristics, called somaclonal variants. At lower frequency, similar variants called sports arise during normal growth. These new variants can have great economic value, but relatively little is known of the causes, nature and evolutionary significance of these phenomena. This project will investigate these changes in potato. The methods suitable to analyze these genomic changes will be applicable to other crops, and will be made available to the scientific and plant breeding community.  Societal impact is expected along two lines. First, this project will address a largely ignored potential source of variation likely to affect leading economic species. Second, the project entails several outreach activities, with two objectives: 1) Familiarize young students in underrepresented communities with science studies and careers and 2) Train advanced students and professionals in genomic approaches applicable to plant breeding. These objectives will be achieved through a combination of publishing in outreach journals, provision of international workshops, and production of learning videos.

The long term goal of this project is to understand the mechanisms and outcomes of genome instability and restructuring. The central hypothesis is that instability, while often deleterious, can also reshape the genome in ways that are less disruptive and potentially adaptive, such as by causing change or loss of heterozygosity, and dosage variation. Elucidating the causes, mechanisms, and consequences of these changes will help clarify their role in natural and artificial selection, and inform prediction, identification and, if appropriate, exploitation of these changes. The work will focus on the autotetraploid potato genome, in which we have documented extensive genomic changes in tissue culture regenerated potatoes, ranging from aneuploidy to indels, extreme rearrangements, but also more subtle changes in heterozygosity consistent with homologous DNA repair. Analysis of variation in potato suggests that genome instability varies according to environment and that it can occur during normal growth. The specific aims are to: i) Characterize the molecular patterns associated with somaclonal variation in potato. By examining resulting rearrangements, hypotheses on potential mechanisms, such as homologous vs. nonhomologous repair of dsDNA breaks, will be tested, ii) Study molecular patterns associated with differentiation of potato clones. Genomic analysis of clonally propagated potato will test the hypothesis that somatic homologous recombination results in variation and, iii) Investigate relation of dsDNA breaks to loss of heterozygosity. This objective will leverage induced and spontaneous loss of heterozygosity models to test possible mechanisms of dsDNA break repair, such as mitotic crossover and break-induced recombination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many cultivated plants are propagated vegetatively. For example, grapevine by cuttings and potato by tubers. During propagation, novel and valuable variants called sports can emerge. This project, funded by NSF award 1956429, aimed at characterizing the molecular mechanisms that underlie clonal variation. Our work has resulted in several key outcomes:


Understanding of how mutation rates vary in the plant growth apex:
The plant body develops from the Shoot Apical Meristem (SAM), which comprises three distinct morphogenetic layers: L1, L2, and L3. The L1 forms the epidermis, the L2 the photosynthetic tissue and gametes, and the L3 the adventitious roots and vascular system. We found that mutations accumulated differentially in the L1 versus the L2+L3, which appear homogeneous. Remarkably, the L1 accumulates more mutations than the L2+L3. As a result, the epidermis is genetically more unstable while the gametes are more stable. The differential accumulation of mutations among the layers helps explain the formation of layer chimeras, some of which have important implications for clonal breeding. Another finding was that mutations accumulated during protoplast regeneration (a possible step in plant manipulation) are often caused by reactive oxygen species, suggesting that cells in the SAM are protected from DNA damage caused by reactive oxygen species.. 

Characterizing the molecular basis of clonal variation: 
We focused on Russet Norkotah (RN), the most important US fresh market potato variety. Several RN clonal variants are widely grown due to their increased vigor and yield.. We sequenced the genome of four popular variants and found that all four displayed a novel allele of a gene called CYCLING DOF FACTOR 1 (CDF1 ). > The new alleles, formed through the excision of a transposable element, resulted in increased expression of CDF1 and delayed tuber maturity, explaining the improved performance of these clonal variants. By providing the likely molecular basis of RN clonal performance, this discovery could contribute to the breeding of new potato varieties.  

Characterizing the molecular basis of twin spot formation:
Homologous recombination during plant growth is important for both basic research and practical applications like gene replacement. However, its frequency and the molecular conditions that promote it remain poorly characterized. Certain plant heterozygotes for a leaf color gene form green-white twin spots on yellow-green leaves. Because each spot displays a homozygous phenotype, these occurrences have often been attributed to homologous recombination between chromosome pairs, resulting in somatic crossovers. Our genomic analyses determined that the twin spots formed by tobacco heterozygous for the sulfur mutation (Su/su), resulted not from homologous recombination but rather from chromosomal breakage, nonhomologous translocation, and aneuploidy. The ratio of the Su - su alleles determined color. This discovery extends our understanding of the mechanisms that alter the genome during plant growth and indicates that somatic recombination between the two chromosomes of a pair is rare. 

Broader Impacts:
The project produced educational videos and articles on general and plant genetics, as well as plant breeding, targeted at students ranging from junior high to college level. 

Products and Dissemination:
We have published several articles in refereed journals both describing the primary research and reviewing the significance of the research. We identified and resolved a material mix-up within the USDA potato collection. Team members have presented results in multiple conferences and seminars.  

Future Directions:
We plan to continue studying the effect of SAM layer organization on other important properties of the genome such DNA methylation and transposon regulation. In addition, we plan to elucidate the practical implications of SAM layer organization for the genetic modification of crops.
